prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: field1_ACTJ0102
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Point sources in the field of cluster ACTJ0102.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a total of 2.2 hours of observing time (including overheads) to obtain band-7 continuum mapping at 1 arc sec spatial resolution for a sample of 39 SMGs detected with LABOCA in the field of five galaxy clusters from the ACT SZE-selected catalogue, for which
Imaging requirements: To map the proposed targets, we opt for the antenna configuration C34-1, which provides an angular resolution of 1.08 arc sec and maximum angular scale of 7.6 arsec. Previous high-resolution imaging of SMGs has shown typical angular sizes from 0.5 arc sec to 3 arc sec (Iono et al. 2006; Tacconi et al. 2006, 2008; Chapman et al. 2008; Swinbank et al. 2010), and ALMA observations of field SMGs indicate that at least 35% of LABOCA sources can be resolved into multiple components. The high 870 micron flux densities of brightest sources in our sample suggest that they are either massive, multiple systems, or that they are lensed by the foreground clusters' gravitational potentials. In either case, the requested resolution will allow us to resolve the dust emission, determine the true nature of each source and match them to plausible far/mid-infrared and optical counterparts.
For Band 7 observations the resulting field of view is 18.2 arc sec, so we can cover the full extent of the LABOCA beam in a single pointing, and confidently locate the sources even if we take into account the ~3 arc sec uncertainty in LABOCA coordinates. Additionally, our targets' expected angular sizes are at most half of the maximum angular scale provided by the selected antenna configuration, so we will recover the totality of point-source flux density but resolve out the extended SZE emission (~1 arcmin angular scale), and thus disentangle both signals. In total, we will perform only one pointing per source.
Requested sensitivity: Our selected targets have been detected as point sources in our LABOCA 345 GHz maps, with peak flux densities of up to 37 mJy at 345 GHz. In order to detect all targets at least at the 4 sigma level, we base our sensitivity requirement estimates on the fainter objects, with LABOCA ~4 mJy/beam. According to previous ALMA Band 7 SMG observations reported in Hodge et al. (2013), systems with LABOCA flux densities as low as 2.5 mJy can be resolved into two point-source components of similar brightnesses, so we assume that our targets could be split into single components with flux densities as low as ~2.5/2=1.25 mJy/beam. For a 4 sigma detection, we therefore require a final sensitivity of 0.3 mJy to secure recovery of all sub millimeter emission. From the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator, this sensitivity limit is reached after ~30 seconds on source, but significant additional time is required for acquisition of calibration data. To minimize overheads, we have organized our observations into 4 Science Goals, so that individual pointings are within 10 degrees of each other. Each Science Goals requires ~ 30 minutes in total, and our total time request is 2.2 hours for the complete survey.
Correlator setup: Our observations will be performed in single continuum mode, with dual polarization. This mode provides four basebands, each of them 2 GHz wide. The central sky frequency is set at 345 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: field3_ACTJ0438

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: field4_ACTJ0546
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Point sources in the field of cluster ACTJ0546.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to obtain band-7 continuum mapping at ~1 arcsec spatial resolution for a sample of 39 submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) detected with LABOCA (~18"/beam) in the field of five galaxy clusters originally detected through their Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect decrement signals at 148 GHz. The selected targets have 870 micron (345 GHz) flux densities ranging from 3.7 to 36.9 mJy, but our current photometric accuracy is compromised by blending of point source and extended SZE emission, and plausibly of multiple fainter SMGs within a single LABOCA beam.
To secure detection of all targets and their possible sub-components at the 4 sigma level, we require a point-source sensitivity of 0.3 mJy. To achieve this observational goal, we require a total observation time of 2.2 hours including overheads.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Andres Bello, University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Wisconsin at Madison, University of
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
National Center for Supercomputing Applications, Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
